indicator_name: Residents living in a hurricane evacuation zone
indicator_long_name: Residents living in a hurricane evacuation zone, 2024
indicator_description: Hurricane Evacuation Zones are determined by New York City Emergency Management and indicate varying threat levels of coastal flooding from storm surge. Evacuation orders may be given during hurricanes or coastal flooding events. There are six zones, ranked by storm surge risk. Zone 1 is the highest risk for flooding. Residents in these zones may receive evacuation orders during hurricanes or tropical storms.
data_source_list: New York City Office of Emergency Management

indicator_name: Daytime summer surface temperature
indicator_long_name: Daytime summer surface temperature, 2018
indicator_description: Surface temperatures vary based on vegetative cover (which promotes cooling), as well as by materials that retain heat (like paved roads, sidewalks, and buildings). Hotter neighborhoods tend to have more heat-exacerbated deaths associated with extreme heat events.
data_source_list: U.S. Geological Survey

indicator_description: Hurricane Evacuation Zones are determined by New York City Emergency Management and indicate varying threat levels of coastal flooding from storm surge. Residents in these zones may receive evacuation orders during hurricanes or tropical storms.

indicator_description: Hurricane Evacuation Zones are determined by New York City Emergency Management and indicate varying threat levels of coastal flooding from storm surge. Evacuation orders may be given during hurricanes or coastal flooding events. There are six zones, ranked by storm surge risk. Zone 1 is the highest risk for flooding. Residents in these zones may receive evacuation orders during hurricanes or tropical storms.
data_source_list: New York City Office of Emergency Management

indicator_name: Daytime summer surface temperature
indicator_long_name: Daytime summer surface temperature, 2018
indicator_description: Surface temperatures vary based on vegetative cover (which promotes cooling), as well as by materials that retain heat (like paved roads, sidewalks, and buildings). Hotter neighborhoods tend to have more heat-exacerbated deaths associated with extreme heat events.
data_source_list: U.S. Geological Survey
